text.value: COVID is very infectious. Because everyone can spread the disease - but does not always have symptoms - it is important to isolate patients, and tell their family members to avoid contact with other people if they have been exposed.

When speaking with your patient by phone or in person, you should assess these symptoms. If the patient shows any symptoms, refer them to the nearest Clinic or Health Center and contact your supervisor about diagnostic testing.
Community health workers play an important role in recognizing covid-19, educating others on how to care for a covid patient, and reducing stigma. After this module you will:

• 1. Know how to minimize stigma associated with COVID infection
  • 2. Know how to assess and risk stratify patients with suspected COVID
    • 3. Know how suspected COVID positive patients can limit contact with others
  • 4. Know key messages to advise on reintegration into the household/society

• - Fever
  • - Difficulty breathing
  • - Bluish lips or face
  • - Ability to drink fluids
  • - Cough
  • - Confusion or change in mental status
  • - Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
  • - Severe dehydration
  • - Inability to wake up or to stay awake
  • - Sore throat
  • - Nausea or diarrhea
  • - Loss of smell
Stay 2 meters away from others, to not come in contact with infected droplets. Do not shake hands or hug. If you are greeting others, wave instead.
In person, evaluate the patient's symptoms from a distance.
Always wear a mask or face covering, and wash your hands afterward.
How to safely and effectively assess a patient

• - Is not someone who is at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19
  • - Monitors patient for severe symptoms such as shortness of breath, dehydration, and changing mental status
  • - Wears face coverings before entering the patient's room and when caring for the patient
  • -Washes hands after any contact with the patient or surfaces they have used
There should be one primary caretaker who:
Confusion or change in mental status
Which possible symptoms of COVID-19 should you always ask about? (Select all that apply)
Refer to local health center for emergency help
Tell patient to stay at home and lie down
A patient has fast breathing, difficulty speaking, and bluish lips, or has a fever, is confused and cannot stay awake. What should you do next?
Recognize when patient requires referral for emergency help
When caring for a suspected COVID-19 patient, what are the two most important parts of your body to cover?
What should you always do immediately after being in the same room as a COVID-19 patient?
Patients are safe to leave the house once it has been at least 10 days since symptoms first appeared AND symptoms have improved AND they have had NO FEVER for at least...
Know key messages to advise on reintegration into the household/society
Most people do not recover from COVID-19
Stigma against COVID-19 causes people to seek health care
Which of the following is true about COVID-19?
Know how to address and minimize stigma associated with COVID infection
If your patient has any of the following symptoms, they should be referred for clinical assessment and care:

• - Fast breathing
  • - Indrawing of chest
  • - Pale or bluish color to lips/mouth
  • - Difficulty speaking
It is important to inform COVID-19 patients of the requirements to rejoin the community and safely interact with family after COVID:

• - They should not have had fever for at least 72 hours (assess this without the use of paracetamol or ibuprofen)
  • - AND other symptoms should have improved
  • - AND at least 10 days should have passed since their symptoms first appeared
Know key messages to advise on reintegration into the household/society
Stigmatization causes more risk when patients:

• - Hide their illness, to avoid being discriminated
  • - Don't seek help or health care immediately
    • - Don't adopt healthy behaviors
Remember that anyone can get COVID. Stigmatizing people can aggravate health problems, increase transmission and make it more difficult to control the outbreak.
Risks of stigmatization during the pandemic

Will you be able to effectively perform on these tasks?
A patient or suspected COVID-19 patient shouldâ€¦

• 1. Wear a face mask around other people
  • 2. Stay home and self isolate
  • 3. Cough into a tissue and throw it away, and wash their hands
  • 4. Rest and drink plenty of water (non-alcoholic liquids)
  • 5. Minimize contact with household members
  • 6. Use their own dishes, silverware, towels, bed, and electronics
  • 7. Avoid having visitors
  • 8. Clean touched surfaces with a disinfectant, especially bathrooms
8. Clean all surfaces, especially those shared, with a disinfectant after use
5. Minimize contact with other household members
4, Rest well and drink plenty of clear, non-alcoholic liquids
1. Wear a cloth face covering when they are around other people
6. Use their own separate dishes, silverware, towels, bed, and electronics
3, Cough into a tissue and throw it away and wash your hands
2. Stay home and self-isolate by not leaving the house as much as possible

• - Cover the nose and mouth with a face mask.
  • - Cover the eyes with protective glasses or a face shield.
  • - Wear a protective garment.
  • - When removing PPE, the outside of the garments cannot touch your face or skin.
  • - Wash your hands before and after wearing PPE.
  • - If your patient needs to be transferred to medical care, they should wear a facemask to protect others.
Effectively use & safe disposal of PPE
PPE includes face masks, gloves, eye glasses or face shields, and protective garments. These items can protect one from being infected by virus-containing droplets.
What is Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) & why is it important?
